Identify Problematic Response Values in SPSS Data

Source: R/labelled_data.R
identify_problematic_values.Rd

**L1 Internal Helper.** Scans value labels to identify codes that represent non-substantive responses (e.g., "Don't know", "Refused", "Not applicable"). These often need to be recoded to NA before analysis.

Usage

identify_problematic_values(
  label_df,
  patterns = c("don'?t know", "dk\\b", "unsure", "refuse", "declined?", "prefer not",
    "not applicable", "n/?a\\b", "missing", "no response", "skipped", "^99+$", "^-9+$",
    "^-1$")
)

Arguments

label_df

Data frame from extract_value_labels() with columns value, label

patterns

Character vector of regex patterns to match problematic labels. Default includes common problematic response patterns.

Value

Data frame subset of label_df containing only problematic values, or NULL if none found. Adds a "reason" column explaining why it was flagged.

Details

**What this identifies:** Response codes that don't represent actual data, such as: - "Don't know" / "DK" / "Unsure" - "Refused" / "Decline to answer" / "Prefer not to say" - "Not applicable" / "NA" / "N/A" - "Missing" / "No response" - Numeric codes like 99, 999, -99, -1 (common SPSS missing codes)

**Why this matters:** These should usually be recoded to NA before computing means, correlations, or other statistics. Otherwise, "99 = Don't know" will be treated as a very high response, inflating your results.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Get labels for a variable
labels <- extract_value_labels(data$satisfaction)

# Find problematic values
problems <- identify_problematic_values(labels)
#   value label              reason
#   99    Don't know         Don't know response
#   -1    Not applicable     Not applicable response
} # }
